episode.title: Board of Ed. of Central School Dist. No. 1 v. Allen

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 660, Board of Education of Central School District number 1, et al. appellants, versus James E. Allen, Jr. as Commissioner of Education of New York, et al.
Mr. Pollock.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: May it please the Court.
The issue in this case is where a consonant with the religious clauses of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.
The State of New York may furnish textbooks purchased with tax raised funds for use in religious schools.
The material facts in the case are not in dispute.
Prior to 1965, Section 701 of the New York Education law, authorized local school boards to purchase textbooks and either to loan or sell them to pupils in the public schools in the state.
In 1965, the provisions relating to textbooks in Section 701 were amended effective September 1, 1966.
The effect of the amendment was to turn a permissive practice into a mandatory one and to extend the coverage of the law to private schools.

Under the law as amended, each school board in New York must purchase and long free of charge to all children residing in its district enrolled in a grade from 7 through 12 of an accredited public or private school any textbook requested by the child so long as the textbook was one designated for use in any public school in the state or by any school board in the state.
As originally enacted, the law contained no limit on the number of books required to be purchased and no limit on the amount of money that had to be spent for the books by the local school district.
It did however provide for state reimbursement or state allocation to the extent of $10.00 a pupil.
In the view of the East Greenbush School Board which had children residing in its district who were enrolled in grade 7 through 12 accredited private religious schools.
The provisions of Section 701 as amended violated both the New York State Constitution and the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution both of which each member had sworn to uphold.
Failure to implement the law on a part of this board would have subjected the members a removal from office and also would have subjected the school district to a loss of state funds.
To resolve this conflict, the Greenbush School Board filed an action in the Supreme Court Albany County.

The relief sought in the complaint was a judgment declaring the Textbook Law to the extent that related to church schools unconstitutional and in violation to both the New York State Constitution on the First amendment to the Federal Constitution.
It also sought an order in joining the State Commissioner of Education from implementing the provisions of the law.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You're objecting only to the adaptation of the statute in the parochial schools, are you not?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You had no constitutional objection to furnish the nonsectarian schools?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: These boards have raised no constitutional objection.

After the suit was filed and the suit incidentally was filed April 29, 1966 which is about four month before the law was to go into effect, after the suit was filed, the Textbook Law was further amended in two respects.
The first respect was to reduce the financial book on the local school boards.
The second respect was to define a textbook as used in the statute to mean a book which a student is required to use as a text for a semester or more in a school he legally attends.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In schools what, I didn't understand?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: In a school he legally attends.
The state answered the complaint, did not raise any material issue of fact but did deny the allegations relating to the unconstitutionality of the law.

The state also raised a number of affirmative offenses, principal one of which was that the Greenbush School Board lacks standing to sue on the ground that it was an instrumentality of the state and could not challenge State Law.
After issue was joined, five parents of children who resided in the East Greenbush School Board were permitted to intervene in the action.
In their answer, they too did not raise any material issue of fact but did deny the allegations of unconstitutionality of the law.
And in addition, they raised a number of affirmative defenses.

The thrust of these defenses was that to deny the books to them and their children while permitting the furnishing of these books to pupils attending private nonsectarian schools constituted an interference with the free exercise of their religion and a denial of due process and equal protection.
All parties then move for judgment.
In substance, judgment on the pleading, they were in all affidavits.
At the time of oral argument, the Board of Education of Union Free School District No. 3 was joined as a party plaintiff and was deemed to have adopted all the pleadings in the case.
The Supreme Court Albany County granted the plaintiff's cross-motion for judgment.

It ruled that the Greenbush -- the two school boards had standing to sue, and also that the law as amended in 1965 and in 1966 violated the State Constitution and both the establishment of free exercise clauses of the Federal Constitution and a judgment was entered to that effect which among other things enjoined the state from implementing the statute.
An appeal was taken to the Appellant Division, third department.

Three of the justices constituting a majority of that court voted to reverse the judgment of the Supreme Court Albany County and dismiss the complaint on the sole ground that the appellants lack standing to sue.
Two remaining justices would have found that the appellants had standing and would have voted to reverse on the merits.
They would have found a law constitutional in all respects.
The case was then appealed to the New York Court of Appeals.
That court reached the merits of the action.
It ruled that the appellants had standing to sue.
And by a four-to-three vote, it ruled that the Textbook Law as amended did not violate State Constitution, did not violate the establishment clause of the Federal Constitution.
Approximately 20 years ago, this Court for the first time defined the scope of the establishment clause's coverage.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Before you get to your main argument, are you going to discuss the question of standing to sue in this Court?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: As far as I know, I would rest on the record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I said as far as I'm concerned, since the standing has been decided and no issue has been raised by the appellees.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well need the standing to sue issue would be the same in this Court as it was in New York?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No, it need not, Your Honor, but --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it in the same posture as it was in New York?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think it is, Your Honor.
I think this case comes --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I thought in New York that they took the school board out of its dilemma by saying that the act was constitutional and they were no longer subject then to any sanctions for not obeying the law of New York, which was the reason that they granted the standing to sue, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, I didn't understand it that way, Your Honor.
I -- as I understood it, they ruled that a state board is not –

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: As I understand, the ruling of the Court on the standing question, they said that the state board has standing to sue and to challenge to the State Law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but you come to this Court, do you not?

And asked us to take jurisdiction because your Board of Education is faced with a dilemma that it cannot out of, namely that if it obeys the law of New York -- I mean if it refuses to obey the law of New York that it's subject to sanctions.
And then the Court of Appeals of New York has now availed that the law is constitutional and they can go forward without any danger of sanctions.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, as far as I can say here, I think if they went ahead and violated the Federal Constitution, it is quite conceivable that they might be subject to other liabilities which have not so far been asserted.
I would think that they might have taxpayer cases exposure if they're spending federal funds in violation of the Federal Constitution or spending state funds in violation of the Federal Constitution.
So I don't think the case would be at an end on that question.
I think that they're not out of the dilemma yet and I would think that if -- until the federal question was decided, this would be an open question.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, it might for some people.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is it for this Court?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I would think so, Your Honor.
I think that there are people in these school districts who might well attack the active spending funds in violation of the -- of what they deem to be in violation of the Federal Constitution.
And that might raise the involved issue again so that they would then be in jeopardy.
They would have the same dilemma that is to risk the violation and to spend the funds or not to risk the violation.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: May I ask you a preliminary -- another preliminary question, please?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm not certain as to whether the act and the regulations make it clear that the only textbooks that can be purchased and furnished to a parochial school are textbooks which are approved by a state authority as distinguished from the governing authority of the parochial schools.
Are you telling me that that is clear in the law and (a) in the law, (b) in the regulations?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I -- I'm not saying that it's clear on the law.
I think Justice Van Voorhis pointed this out in his dissent on the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright.
Now what about the regulations?
They seem -- I can't look at where they --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: The regulations are attached as an appendix to the appellant's brief beginning at page 4a.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Because when I read them, I thought that the ambiguity to say the least was carried over.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think in part --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Into the regulations.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think in part, it is.
The --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What did the Court of Appeals say about it?
Not to the center but the New York Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't think that they raised the question.
They assumed that the books would be secular.
I think that they're saying that the statute -- construing the statute to require the giving of secular books --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's right, but that's the same.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: -- as designated --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm pointing out the difference between secular textbook and who prescribes it.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I understand, Your Honor.
I think the New York Court of Appeals, as I understand it, did not get into that question.
They just said that the books would be prescribed by public authorities without -- I don't think that they found any problem with the language of the statutes in majority of places.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I confess that that bothers me because the statute does read as if the statute says that the textbooks should be those that are designated for use or are approved by any Boards of Education trustees or other school authorities.
It might make substantial difference in this case if the parochial schools have the power to designate the textbooks, secular textbooks that are then purchased by the state funds.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that would raise a definite problem, Your Honor.
And as I said, Justice Van Voorhis was bothered with that in the Court of Appeals.
The majority I think this one had on the basis that the statute meant to them that it was the public authorities who designated the book.
They did not do anything more than quote the language of the statute as I read the opinion and said that this is what it is, that the public authorities are the ones that designate the books.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then, may we take that as an interpretation for the New York statute regulations?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What the Court said, what the majority said.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's what -- I don't know why.
I think that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they said, as I gather and you believe they did, whether they assumed to however they did it in effect that they must be textbooks designated by the public authority, why isn't that an interpretation upon which we should proceed?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think for federal questions involved in this case, I don't know why we should bound here by the construction --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But we can't construe the New York statute and regulations if the Court of Appeals has given that definitive construction, can we?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure that it did and I've read that opinion and I don't know that it did.
I think it cited the statute and then said that they went into the secularity of the books but didn't do anything more than that.
As I understand it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think it's satisfactory how that the books to be improved happen to be secular books?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that's what it said.
That's what it said the statue has.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I don't want to take any more of your time.
I agree with you on page 67a of the appendix.

The Court of Appeals said that textbooks have to be secular, but I -- perhaps I overlooked or have forgotten where they said that they have to fix – such the books have to be designated or approved by a public authority.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think again, if I may read from the Court of Appeals' opinion, they say that only textbooks designated for use by the public schools are approved by Boards of Education, trustees or school authorities may be lent and inside the statute.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's just according to statute.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
They do not go on to say --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The phrase “school authorities” --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: They do not define that in this opinion.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that I haven't been able to find in here any narrowing down of this troublesome language as I see it that appears in the statute.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
I don't think the Court did define that in the opinion.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, for the purposes of your argument, what interpretation of the statute do you want us to assume here?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, I would say that we could assume here that the books are designated by the public authorities and not the parochial schools --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And not by the religious authorities.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Religious authorities of the parochial schools.
We could assume that and still find the statute to be unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And do you think we're entitled to take that position?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't think so but I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What position do you want us to think we ought to take?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think you ought to take the position that the statute is vague and is susceptible of the construction of the parochial schools may actually designate the books.
I think in implementation, this is probably how in part it could work out anyhow.

But I think that even if the statute is not construed that way, I think that the law is still bad so that I would be satisfied if this Court were to construe the statute to mean that the public authorities designate the books.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Have you argued this in your brief?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I have not.
I have --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Have you assumed in your argument below and in this Court that these books were to be prescribed by a public authority?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I have maybe -- I have assumed that's the case, but I have also argued that religious schools may play a role in the selection –

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: May play -- the religious schools may play a role in the selection of books.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In what?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: In the selection of books.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Prescribed by whom?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, prescribed by the public authorities, but I have argued that the public authorities in many cases consist of a Board of Education elected by the residence of the particular school district and in some cases, I think where -- particularly where some religious group has let's say an ethnic majority, they do have power to elect the people to the board who are more prone to follow their views.
And once this board is elected and does have the power to designate books, it would not be unusual to have these books.
These boards designate books which are not contrary to the face which they hold.
I think to that extent, you have some involvement or some possibility of involvement.
So whether the books are designated by a public authority, the public authority itself is made up of people.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On the brief of the appellee, it stated categorically that the statutory reading on the footnote on page three of the intervener appellee's brief, the statutory definition of “school authorities” in Education Law Section 2 Subsection 12 makes it plain that this phrase, that is the phrase school authorities, which means the public school authorities.
Do you quarrel with that?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think I quarrel with the statement that it makes it plain.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's statutory definition.
The statutory -- what is the statutory definition in Section 2(12)?
I refer to that on page three of school authorities.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Trustees of a Board of Education or corresponding officers, whether one or more and by whatever name known of a city school district or other school districts however created.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there a definition there of school --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes, there is.

The term school authorities means that trustees or Board of Education or corresponding officers, whether one or more and by whatever name known of a city school district or other school districts however created.
Now that that might -- that would define, presumably define school authorities.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Will public schools are in addition there?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes, it would.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And only public schools?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
That would define the term “school authorities”.
But not define the term boards of education --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What conclusions does that lead you to then on this thing that we've been discussing?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I take it that there is a question in my mind, and I don't know that anybody can solve it by even going to the construction laws to whether or not the books must be designated by a public authority.

I think there's some question in the statute and I think even if there is no question, that there is -- the books must be designated for use by a public authority, I think you still have the problem that the public authority could consist of eight Board of Education anywhere in the state who has the right to designate books.
And I think I have suggested in my brief that this does make the act susceptible to parochial interference.
If a school board is dominated by a faith, it can designate books for use.
Then, school boards anywhere else in the state or children anywhere else in the state can order that book.
And once the book is on the list --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In other words, your position is that if the school board in Buffalo, New York prescribed certain books that the children in New York would demand those books and you got them and used them in a manner that the statute contemplates.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That is your concern of the statute?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That is my construction of the statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was that argued below?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was that argued here --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in your brief?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Court is quite apart from this statute that we're talking about now, is that if the members of a particular religious sect got control of any public school board, they could I suppose voice upon the public school system and -- over which they had jurisdiction in all sorts of religious propaganda in the form of textbooks, if that's your imaginary horrible, and I suppose that could happen –

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: It could happen.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- with or without this statute, right in the public schools.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: But I think in --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They could begin indoctrinating public schools children and these tenants of the Lutheran Church for example if the little three missionaries got control of the particular school board.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think it could well happen.
I think what's happened in a good many of the school districts in New York, textbooks are not supplied by the schools.
And I think where you have tax funds raised to be spent for books you might have more action in this area if you do at present.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I suppose that you're answer to Justice Stewart's question would be that if that happened, if this was a school board, a public school board funneling religious tracks with public money to protect your school, that could be on the constitution.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
The same problem would exist and that would be the one step.
I have posed the two step situation, but that would be an infirmity in spending in that instance, too.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So that would set the courts out there to judge it as to how much of any religious propaganda that were in any particular textbook?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No, I think that would -- we would have to -- we would have to find out what the -- where the public funds are being used.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You might suggest we might do a better job with that than we've been doing in the Senate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That would be at least as difficult.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does the State Board of Education in New York have anything to do with the textbooks in the various districts?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: They have a right of oversee generally.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was that?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: They have a right of supervision of all the local board and Boards of Education.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: As to what books are you --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I take it that they would decide questions of as to whether a particular book ought to be used or should not be used.
They would be the ultimate authority on it I see on that connection.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They're the ultimate authority.
Thanks.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I beg your pardon.
What is the status of this opinion of the counsel that perhaps to your brief, is that to be considered as a regulation of the Board of --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think it is.
I think the counsel is charged with the implementation --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What bothers me then is that the statute uses only the term “textbooks”.
It does not say “secular textbooks”.
That's number one.
Number two, the opinion of the counsel as I read it, which it says to be considered as a regulation, and provides that textbook shall be non-sectarian.
It just eliminates, it says, denominational editions and those carrying the “imprimatur” or “nihil obstat” of a religious authority.
It says non-sectarian and does not say secular and there is a difference, isn't there?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes, there is.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And it's only when you get to the opinion -- majority opinion of the Court of Appeals here so far as I know that you find the qualification on the word “textbooks” meaning that -- as saying secular.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: There's nothing in the statute that I see and there is the possibility of difference in the substance with the opinion of the counsel or regulations to which I have referred.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: These have the -- these have binding force on the school boards throughout the state, the opinion of counsel, I understand.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well at least--

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: It was issued after the case was argued about it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If there is an inconsistency between the opinion of counsel and the judgment of the New York Court of Appeals, which would prevail as to the construction of this statute?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: The New York Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: In the Everson case, which was decided by this Court 20 years ago, the Court defined the scope of the establishment clause as coverage.
The definition consisted of seven sentences that appears at 330 US 15 and is quoted at page 10 of appellant's brief.

One of the sentences reads that no tax in any amount, large or small, can be levied to support any religious activities or institutions whatever they may be called or whatever form they may adopt to teach or practice religion.

While four justices in that case disagreed with the application of that definition to the facts of Everson, all of the justices agreed with the definition, and the definition has been repeated and reaffirmed at least three times, once unanimously until a Castle against Watkins in 1961.

In applying the Everson definition to the facts of the case, the majority started out by saying that state legislation should not be overturned if it was within the state's constitutional power even though it approached the verge of that power.

Said on the one hand New Jersey could not, consistent with the establishment clause, contribute tax funds for the support of any religious institution which teaches the tenants in faiths of any church.
Presumably here, it had in mind church schools.

On the other hand, New Jersey could not interfere with the free exercise of religion by their citizens such as by excluding believers or non-believers because of their faith or lack of it from the benefits of any welfare legislation.
But the issue does pose it remained only for the majority there to determine the nature of the benefit, which was bus transportation, of where and how it was used.
And it determined that bus transportation was like certain other government services such as police and fire protection, sewage disposal, streets and highways.

The reason that it was no different than these other services the Court suggested was that it was separate and indisputably marked off from the primary function of the school, which was the teaching of religion.
In other words, funds, tax funds were not being used by or within the confines of a religious institution in connection with functions associated with religion.

Having determined that the funds -- that the benefit was marked off from the religious function, the Court concluded New Jersey did not support religion, although Justice Rutledge agreed to the definition of the scope of the establishment clause, he disagreed with the majority's conclusion that the busing law did not support religion.
For him, the primary reason children was sent to a church school was to obtain a religious education.
The payment of transportation not only helped them get there and their parents to send them, but it aided them in this objective.
And any aid to religion was outlawed and was intended to be outlawed.
The dual prohibitions for Justice Rutledge to the first amendment made religion a private matter and it could not be made public by legislation.
The question of whether the tax funds or funds were raised for a public purpose was for him a false issue, clouding a real issue of the first amendment span.

In summary, Everson said as I read the case that busing or the providing of bus transportation approached the verge of New Jersey's constitutional power but that it was permissible because it was separate and marked off from the religious function of the church school.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well are you asking us to take the opinion of Everson or the dissenting opinion Mr. Justice Rutledge that you've just been talking about?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that the -- if the majority opinion were accepted in Everson, it would require that textbooks -- textbook aids would be prohibited.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you stand on the --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I would stand on the majority --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in the Everson case?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, I would.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I wonder if you would mind telling us just what difference on the facts there is between the Everson case and this one.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think in this case, a textbook, unlike bus transportation, is not separate and marked off from the primary function of a church school, which is the teaching of religion.
The very opposite is true that transportation takes children to the door of a school but textbook aid spills over to the classroom.
A textbook is an integral part of the educational process which takes place in a church school.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't getting the children there an integral part of it?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I do not think so, Your Honor.
I do not think it has -- relates at all to the educational process which takes place in the school.
And I think that's the difference between giving textbooks and giving bus transportation.
Textbooks are an essential element of education.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What would you say of the health programs that they?
Or take -- let's take the school lunch program that they have in the schools.
What would you say about that as to whether that is in accord with Everson or not?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I would think assuming there was no proselytizing in connection with him -- with these benefits I would say that the benefits were not impermissible because while they might be used in a religious institution, the benefits, they are not used in connection with the teaching of religion, which is the primary function of these schools.
They are not connected to the teaching of the tenants of that church which is the primary mission of that school.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then supplying non-religious books, is there any proselytizing --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think there is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in that act?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think there is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What -- to what extent and what effect?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: A textbook, unlike a reference book or a book in general is not intended to be used by a student alone as a rule.
Its contents cannot be fully utilized until subjected to the interpretation and analysis of a teacher.
The book is used in a place where the syllabus that teacher, the curriculum and the whole atmosphere is oriented toward a religious objective.
The fact that it's secular makes no difference.

It makes no difference because if the states supply desks, blackboards, chairs, or other so-called secular items of education, it would still be aiding in the educational process which takes place in the school.
These are other items which are directly related to the educational process taking place in the school.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That would include school lunches?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: It would not include school lunches.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What about the health facilities for schools?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I do not think it would include health facilities.

Again, if the aid is not used in connection with functions associated with religion, it does not necessarily fall -- it would depend I assume on whether -- well, if it doesn't, if it's not used in connection with functions associated with religion, it would not be impermissible.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would it be alright to give free eyeglasses so they could read?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think it would be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, wouldn't it be just as easy to give them the books so they could read with their new eyeglasses?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think one is related to a health matter and I think it is more like health than like a tool in the educational process.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's pretty hard to get education if you can't read.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I agree with you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What about if they did -- how about if they gave hearing aids to the youngsters so they could -- so they could better hear in school?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would that be contributing to it because of the idea of religion?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.
I think again that our position has been that certain kinds of benefits which are not directly related to the teaching process which goes on in that school are permissible.

These would include some health measures -- I think the in-school dental treatment, in-school medical treatment, those programs are usually not susceptible to the kind of proselytizing that goes on in connection with what goes on in the classroom.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose you'd make a difference between a posture chair for the children on the one hand and the hearing aid on the other because one chair would have nothing to do with hearing anything or seeing anything or religion -- religious, but the other would.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think if it had to do with the teaching process and forwarded that and it was connected with the teaching process, whatever the item is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you use them in schools.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: The posture chairs --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They would use them in the school class, of course.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think with the textbooks, we have no problem.
I think textbooks are quite different than a chair.
And I think again, you can get into many categories.
One, you can talk about medical items.
You can talk about physical items that is -- such as a posture chair, but I think here, we're talking about one of the three essentials of a school.
A school cannot do without pupils, teachers, and textbooks.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Without pupils getting to the school.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No, it can't do without pupils in the school, Your Honor.

I think too, the one thing that's important to observe is that a church school -- that if books are an integral part of the educational process and a church school is a religious institution, then the furnishing of books constituted -- constitutes a use of tax raised funds for the support of religion.
I think that textbooks are indeed an integral part of what takes place inside of a church school.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This record does -- does this record show how secular books are actually used in a parochial school to further the school's religious aims?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No, it does not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's no evidence of the record in that?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No evidence in the record at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what about an algebra book?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or a geometry book, is that -- is that book when it's being used by a teacher in a parochial school so intimately related to teaching religion?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think it is, Your Honor.
I think that the -- the basic purpose of a church school --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You have to sustain this.
I mean, this is hard -- this is your toughest case isn't it?
Geometry book or --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't know that it is.
I -- I think it's less -- less tough that idea of giving a religious missile --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Tell me about that book as to how it furthers the religious aim of the school.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Well, I think the religious -- as I understand it, the basic purpose of a church school is to teach religion.
For example, in Justice Jackson's dissenting opinion in Everson, he referred --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let's accept that for the moment.
Now, tell me --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Are we going to accept the moment that a church school is a religious institution and that it's dedicated to furthering only religious objectives?
Because if we accept that I think, Your Honor, I think that the textbooks cannot be given to a church school.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Nor anything else.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Nor anything else --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: -- that's related to the educational process of the school.
That's all we're asking here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where do you -- we have read that it furthers only religion, is that what you said?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: As I understand it, the basic purpose of a school, of a religious school is the teaching of the tenants and faith of the church in all courses and in everything.
And I think that any educational aid that's given to them is used to further that mission.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What authority do you have in that state?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think -- as I understand it, no one has denied that a church school is a religious institution, that it's --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is it true that they have people of other faiths in there?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I understand that there are -- there are people of other faiths sometimes in a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they survived.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I understand they do survive.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you think --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you say that the only thing they teach is religion.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that the orientation in these schools -- the basic --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Didn't you say the only thing they teach is religion?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Not a course called religion but I think that the concepts of the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When they were examined by the state board, aren't they required to maintain the same amount of teaching as the public school had maintained?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't know that they're required to maintain.
They are required to meet, as I understand it, certain minimum standards.
I don't know the amount of oversee and supervision in this connection, so I can't say.
They are required to meet certain minimum requirements, but they can do so.
As I understand it, the law is liberally applied to permit them to do so.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But I'm getting trouble with this as you understand it.
You are charging that the parochial schools exist solely for the purpose of teaching religion.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think primarily they do.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the statute then I would suppose is that you would suggest it's just unconstitutional on its face.
Now, are we getting to any questions of whether the books are secular or not or who approves them or anything else?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That the state's detestation that the goal is lost to -- to further a secular goal of education.
It's just false.
It should not be accepted at all.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that the effect of the law is to (a) that the teaching process which goes on in this school, and I think that the principal teaching process is the teaching of religion.
I do not think -- I think that religion permeates at a religious school and everything that's taught there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Including geometry?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Including geometry, and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You don't have any --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think that if you -- the kind is for example, with respect to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What are we supposed to do, take the judicial notice of that or?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I think so.
I don't know whether this Court has taken judicial notice.
I think the courts thus far have.
I think for example, the kind of law the church -- relating to church schools for the Catholic church will, one example, provide -- which I understand --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, in your position -- and we would have to first -- the predicate for your argument is that this is -- that these are religious schools.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Religious institution, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that if -- I suppose some schools could be less related to a sect vis-à-vis.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I don't know.
I would not -- I would say that any school chartered as a religious school would fall within the ban.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Chartered as a religious school?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
I think there are special laws that cover these.
I think that any -- I think it's clear where a school is connected with a sect and there may be some cases where it might be difficult to determine whether there is some formal sect in action.
But I think in most cases, it isn't, that it's clear that this school is operated as a part of the church.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well then why would you say that if a religious school was furnishing free lunches and the state suddenly came along and furnished the free lunches for the children in this religious school, why wouldn't that be bad?
Because they're certainly aide to the school and the school is totally a religious institution.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Because I would say that does not further the education -- that's not connected with the educational process of the school and I'd say that that is the difference but it does in further religion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What do you mean, if not connected with the functions which aide religion.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That is correct.
And I would say functions that aide religion teaching out --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you think the Algebra class is a functionating religion although the lunch would --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes I do.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you make any distinction between the elementary schools and the higher education?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Collegiate education.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No Your Honor.
This statute applies to -- as I understand it to junior high school students alone -- so of course -- this would cover children in 12-year-old to 16-year-old.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How can you distinguish the exemption, tax exemptions from the thing of this kind?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I can't Your Honor.

I think that the tax exemptions is something that had been imbedded in our history and perhaps due to lack of taxpayer standing or litigants in some cases, they haven't been raised in other cases of -- they have existed and I don't distinguish.
I think it would be difficult except of course an exemption is not a direct grant of money, so negative, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So if you are to prevail, you believe that we would also be required to take away the exemption of all church taxation, all church school taxation.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: No, I don't Your Honor.
I think you could limit yourself in this case by giving of textbooks.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I'm speaking about your principle.

I ask you what you believed and you said, you believe that if you were right here that they had -- or not entitle to any taxation or any exemption of taxation, now, that being true wouldn't the principle apply there?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Your Honor, I haven't gone.
I haven't explored the question of tax exemption in this case.
It's not been an issue and I don't pretend to be an authority on it.
The -- what we're asserting here is that textbooks which are given for use in a church school violate the constitution.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: On that theory, would the action of the zoning board in zoning an area to permit building of a practical school be an aid to establish into it?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: In this case -- I would argue only in this case.
The issue here is whether a textbook should be given to parochial schools.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But I suppose we have --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: The definition --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I suppose we have to consider doubling the -- were you principle if we agreed with you to carry us.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: The principle could be I think narrowly drawn if necessary in this case to outlaw textbooks only.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How narrowly could we draw so as to take your position on textbooks and not interfere with anything else?
Will you give us the formula that we could use?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: I suggest that the rule that the text -- that giving of textbooks for use in church schools violates the establishment clause of the First Amendment on a ground that it constitutes a use of tax funds for the support of religion.
Now, that is the rule I'm suggesting that this Court adopt.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is part of the very educational classroom process --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that you're distinguished -- you could distinguish that from this other kind of situations on that basis, couldn't you?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct.
I have reserved ten minutes for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How about scientific equipment for laboratory?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Although that's not involved in this case, I would say that if it were given for use in connection with the teaching functions in the school, the further the mission of the school, teaching the tenants in the face of its religion, it would not be permitted.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That would go for the blackboard school too?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: Yes Your Honor that would go for blackboard--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Anything.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_pollock
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Pollock
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor to church schools.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mrs. Coon.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Initially, I think what I would like to do is to give some observations to some of the questions of this Court which were directed to Mr. Pollock.
As to the issue of standing to sue being raised in this Court, no one has raised it.
We have considered that the issue withstanding to sue was one of State law.

It relates to the peculiar problems and provision of State law and the interpretation which the State Courts have placed upon standing to sue and that the decision by the New York Court of Appeals that under these particular circumstances, the East Greenbush and School Board had standing to sue that it was foreclosed from consideration in this Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I thought I did see your motion of James E. Allen, Jr. to dismiss one of jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: It's for one of jurisdiction based upon what we felt were prior decisions of this Court which involved not a question -- it was not a question of standing the sue it involved the merits of the sue itself.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: One that involved the merits?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How do you reconcile the agreements?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How do you reconcile the proposition with the state of the agreements of standing as foreclosing this Court by reason --

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: The standing to sue which was raised was standing to sue under state law and now a question of the general right of a taxpayer as may have it raised in this Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but it wasn't the (Inaudible) that questions standing the sue in New Jersey which New Jersey sustained what this Court said.
That's a problem here that federal question.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes but I think that it has been considered I think by all the parties in this case if this was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't suppose -- I don't suppose what the parties considered if the standing question is considered -- that the parties don't want us to consider which --

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Certainly, if this Court were, itself, to consider that standing to sue is a problem of this Court, you certainly decide it on that basis.
But the issue that was raised --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what happened in -- wasn't it?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes, I believe it was.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I'm just wondering.

In the statement of the case here in the jurisdiction -- statement as to jurisdiction, it's contended that these people were in a dilemma and that they were obliged either to obey the New York law or be subject to sanctions and that's what got them into and still they have the duty to take care of the children now.
Your Court of Appeals held that they were no longer in a dilemma.
They held that the Act was constitutional and how was that give them standing here?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Well, I would assume that the initial problem which raised their -- which started the sanction was that the members of the Board themselves, felt that the law was unconstitutional both under the state and Federal Constitutions.

And that while the New York Court of Appeals as the final arbiter to the state constitution provisions that they will still consider that there is a question and a dilemma raised for them under the Federal Constitution that if they still believe that the Court of Appeals was an error as to the Federal Constitutional question then and until they got a decision on the merits from this Court, they would still be faced with their own personal dilemma of either refusing to bail a law which they consider it to be unconstitutional federally or face the sanctions of the Education law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But the fact is that they state in their statement of jurisdiction that they are in a legal dilemma that they cannot act without subjecting themselves to some kind of sanctions and the New York Court of Appeals has held that they are -- they can be subject to no sanction for the simple reason that the law in which they are obliged to act under the Court of Appeals order is constitutional.
So doesn't that quite bother the premise upon which they come to this Court?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: But certainly wipe out the premise if they were contending to accept the decision.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: They would wipe out that premise if they are willing to accept the decision of the New York Court of Appeals on the issue of constitutionality which apparently they are not since they are here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But certainly, they don't expect us to say that the New York statute is unconstitutional according to New York Constitution do they?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No sir but they were hoping that you will say it's unconstitutional in the Federal Constitution and since they as public officials in New York not only to uphold the statement but also the Federal Constitution.
That would be if they would have an issue in there.
As to the questions to who designates these books.

Mr. Justice Fortas question was one that somewhat a surprise to us because I don't think anyone in New York has ever assume that anyone -- other than the public school officials and public school boards for the final -- once we have the control over the designation of the books.
The terms --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you don't suggest that the books that are maybe designated are books that are actually used in the public school.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They maybe any kind of a book as long as the public authority will approve them.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And except that they must be secular?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No, a secular text.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean that's what the court says?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: That's what the court said and I think this is what the statute had in mind because when the -- when the statute said --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This is what the Attorney General said?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The Attorney General said nonsectarian that's different isn't.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: I suppose it is but I think we were -- this is not what we were --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, it's an important --

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes, I think that the Attorney General has said not sectarian in this --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And he's made it clear by that parenthetical remark in 6(a) of his ruling that he's talking about in anyway, when he says nonsectarian, he means nonsectarian and not secular.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Oh sir.
I'm sorry Mr. Justice Fortas that I do not know you're referring to that.
The opinion of the counsel of the education department is not an opinion of the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, what is a rule?
What's the status of this?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Well, the status of this is, is that as an opinion actually from our office, it's an advisory opinion only.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well your adversary said that he didn't spend that this was binding but correct me if I'm mistaken.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: I think that the counsel –-

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You think it's not?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: -- no, the counsel of the education department like the New York Attorney General would like very much to have his opinions binding but they are entered in an advisory capacity only.

The only authority that an opinion of the counsel to the education department has is that it maybe supposed to represent the policy of the education department and the commissioner and therefore in a proceeding before the commissioner to appeal from a determination of a local school board.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Where are the regulations of the board of region stand that are referred to in the statute?

The statute says that such textbooks are to be loan free to such children such rules and regulations that fare maybe prescribed by the Board of Regents and such Board of Education trustees or other school authorities.
Now where the regulation -- or the Board of Regents is this is not --

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: As far as I know, the opinion of the counsel -- it's the only thing approaching a rule of regulations --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No ma'am, but I want to know what the opinion of the counsel is why it's here.
Is this to be considered to be the regulations of the Board of Regents prescribed by the expressed language of the statute or is it not -- there would be an answer to that?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: This is not as far as I know that adopted as the rule and regulation of the board.
The counsel of the education department is of course also accounts into the Board of Regents.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And you say there are no regulations prescribed by the Board of Regents despite the language of the statute.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No.

I believe that the language of course also refers to regulation to be adopted by local school boards and I think it has been left to the local school boards within the framework of the advisory opinion of the education department.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The statute used the word end here.
It's something of a miss.
Now, is there anywhere that we can get access on the official source of which we can take notice to a list of the books that have actually been approved or whatever it may be.
It's not in this record.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No sir.
As far as I know, there is no compilation of these texts.
They are determined by individual school boards.

Each public school board in the state has the authority to designate the textbooks to be used in that particular school district to public school district and they also, under the statute, approved upon request of the individual students to request additional textbooks which are not authorized -- already designated for use in public schools but may also request that time an additional book which the board may approve or may not approve as it see is fit.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, let me get clear about this.
I'm sorry to take time on this but we have one kind of case here if this statute means in his reply so exclusively with respect to secular books.
By that, I mean secular books.
I don't mean nonsectarian books.

We have another kind of case in my judgment if the statute is used to public funds to purchase either religious books or sectarian -- in the sectarian sense or in a nonsectarian sense but it's still religious books.
I think we've got the quite different considerations that apply in those two instances.

And so far as I am concerned here as I said here, in the absence of any regulations by the Board of Regents, the situation is far from clear and now, as I understand you, you're telling me that the actual approval of these books is by the local boards of education public bodies, is that right?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that -- does that ever go to the Central Board of Regents?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: It would only go to the Board of Regents or particularly to the Commissioner of Education if a local taxpayer in one of the school districts disputed a termination of the local school board, possibly someone who objected to a book which they felt was sectarian or religious and nonsectarian sense.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Right.
And now --

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: They can appeal to the commissioner --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, you're also telling us though that there no directions to the boards of education that within a broad word of the statute which regarding with textbooks.
There has been no instruction of the Board of Education of this various communities that the word textbook in the statute means only secular textbooks.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No sir except from the framework of this opinion which has been given.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, this opinion was handed down that the statute has been an operation whatever that opinion means.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: No sir.
It was handed down after the original argument of this case in Supreme Court Albany County but not after the statute went into operation.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: This was an advice to the school districts on how they were to go about purchasing the textbooks, what book are to be involved and how also you will see in there the process for processing the reimbursement provisions.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And you're also telling us in any child -- any school of the child if he decides that he wants such and such a book, is that right?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: It can apply to the Board of Education?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: He may if it is a textbook which he is required to use in a school.
He can't decide that some book he seen in the library would make a good book and bring to him at home and apply for that one.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: But I think that it should be made clear that the distinction here is between these textbooks are by law required to be provided to the students and not to the schools they attend.
And that it is the individual request of the student which is involved here.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Can you say that there's no way at all for us to have access to a list that shows whether in fact the word textbook in the statute has been construed in its broad sense in which without qualification, it's used in the statute in the sense of nonsectarian as used in the opinion of counsel to the Department of Education or in the still narrow sense of secular as used in the majority opinion of the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: I could inquire of the education any problem where there has been any further implementation since the decision of the Court of Appeals which refers to secular.
As far as I know, there has not and as far as I also -- as far as I know that there have not been any list of what textbooks are involved.
But I can inquire of the department to find out if they have any list but I don' believe that they have.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there any implementation of 704, I think it is that says it can have subversive textbooks? Is there any regulation or anything of the sort of the Board of Regents?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: I don't know whether there has been any list promulgated of any textbooks which they consider subversive or not.

I think the question usually arises in relation to a request to the counsel of the education department or an opinion to whether or not a particular textbook is permissible in use or may arise an issue of a taxpayer bringing a proceeding an appeal to the commissioner from a determination of a school board to use a text which they would consider to be subversive.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What agency in New York has supreme authority in finding the cause to determine what textbooks will be used by the student?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: The Commissioner of Education.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the regents?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: Well, the regents of course, the Commissioner of Education.
Some of the regions could adapt regulations also with the general authority -- administrative authority over the administration of the education law is in the Commissioner of Education.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what about the Board of Regents?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
turn.text: As supervised by the Board of Regents -- the Board of Regents is a general policy making organization.
I don't think they -- as a rule, do not get down to the individual question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do they not have authority over the books even in going to libraries as well as the schools?

turn.speaker: jean_m_coon
turn.label: Ms. Jean M. Coon
